content.title: Hungarian Parliament, crown of the Republic

introduction.small: Welcome to the pride of the Hungarian nation, 18tth-century monument located on the Eastern bank of the Danube River.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hungarian Parliament, crown of the Republic

paragraphs.text:
In front of the 1956 Hungarian Revolution memorial, on the Kossuth Lajos Square, the third largest parliament in the world (spread over 18,000 sqm) stands proud. This neogothic masterpiece of 691 rooms also showcases Renaissance and Baroque influences. The excessiveness of the project, completed in 1904, can be found in the gilding (40 kilos of gold being used), the fine detail of the stained-glass windows, the 242 sculptures that adorn the place, the spectacular cupolas and the frescoes that dress up the ceilings. The 96-metre high dome is visible all around town.
The 45-minute guided tours will present you the ornamental stairs, the House of Magnates and the Holy Crown of Hungary, displayed in the Main Hall. Book your tickets in advance to avoid long waiting lines, for the House of the Nation, still seat of the National Assembly, remains one of the most popular attractions of the capital.

1055 Budapest

content.title: Galerie Art+Text, Budapest looks Hungary's future in the eyes

introduction.small: Only two steps away from Liberty Square and the Danube River, gallery owners defend a bold approach to contemporary art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galerie Art+Text, Budapest looks Hungary's future in the eyes

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 2014 by two specialists passionate about art history who had already published various books on the topic, the ART + TEXT Gallery offers wall space to upcoming artists as well as recognised masters from the 60s and 70s. Set up on the first floor of the famous Bedő House, architectural marvel built in 1903 that also shelters the House of Hungarian Art Nouveau, it displays the work of many avant-garde creators, at once modern and of their time.
Photographs, sculptures and installations take centre stage in a space devised as the missing link between Hungarian contemporary art and the international scene. Whether aimed towards abstraction or, on the contrary, drawing inspiration from social issues, the exhibited pieces will hold your interest.
The gallery also publishes its own magazine on Magyar arts. The feeling will linger on ground floor, where you will find the Art Nouveau Café that serves local pastries.

content.title: Szimpla Kert, iconic ruin bar

introduction.small: As the first romkért (ruin bar) of Budapest in the old Jewish neighbourhood, Szimpla Kert is an institution governed by alternative cultures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Szimpla Kert, iconic ruin bar

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 2002 in one of these deserted buildings of the old Jewish neighbourhood, Szimpla Kert launched the “ruin bar” trend and is now an emblem of Budapest. It originated from the underground culture that wished to avoid destruction of run-down historical buildings. Nowadays, Szimpla Kert shelters a dozen bars and small restaurants over the two floors of the building. Wander from room to room and explore their varying universes, even though they share the same alternative mindset, only arranged with salvaged elements, like fishnets and barbershop chairs. It will undoubtedly be the only place where you can experience pre-dinner drinks in a bathtub or an old Trabant, the famous East-German car! More than a night time meeting spot, Szimpla Kert hosts events such as concerts, flea markets and outdoor film screenings. Come back on Sunday morning and discover a totally different atmosphere at the farm market, open to all.

content.title: Hilda, grill house in a historical building

introduction.small: In a 17th-century building amid Budapest's 5th district, Hilda is a restaurant devoted to grilled poultry.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hilda, grill house in a historical building

paragraphs.text:
The smell of food coming out of the restaurant will take you back to childhood, for instance when your parents walked you to the food market on Sunday mornings. You will find the origin of that delicious smell displayed on the huge revolving spits roasting poultry. Yes, this is Hilda's speciality, serving roast chicken, duck and turkey, in the Lipótváros neighbourhood. Nearby, a large mosaic fresco depicts a waitress in Art Deco fashion. If you happen to crave for something else than meat, the restaurant also serves lactose free, gluten free and vegetarian dishes, as well as a breakfast menu.
Looking for authentic flavours, Hilda exclusively use local and organic products. The restaurant's success owes a lot to this philosophy, not mentioning the unique setting: a 17th-century building conceived by Jozsef Hild, the famous Hungarian architect who designed St. Stephen's Basilica.

content.title: Dobrumba, from the Bosporus to Gibraltar

introduction.small: At Dobrumba, in Budapest's Jewish district, share multicultural food, from the Mediterranean to the Middle-East and Caucasia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dobrumba, from the Bosporus to Gibraltar

paragraphs.text:
At the crossroads of Dob and Rumbach streets in Budapest, the restaurant simply draws its name from the location. And yet, Dobrumba's influences cannot be further away from these Hungarian alleyways: “From the Atlas Mountains to Ararat, from the Bosphorus to Gibraltar”, it proudly states, almost like a slogan.
With a New York bistro feel in an industrial loft, Dobrumba offers a large selection of mezze to share, as well as Mediterranean, Levantine and even Caucasian recipes. Dip in some Lebanese hummus, and try Israeli labneh (savoury yogurt), Georgian pkhali (spinach-based dish with beetroots and pomegranate), Spanish patatas bravas, Moroccan harira (lentil and chick pea soup) or why not some Turkish kumpir (tomato, feta cheese and yogurt-stuffed baked potato)... With your family or friends, wandering from flavour to flavour has never been more pleasurable.

content.title: Mazel Tov, Mediterranean flavours in Hungary

introduction.small: In the popular District 7, brimming with typical “ruin bars”, this Mediterranean grill and street food restaurant comes out of hiding.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mazel Tov, Mediterranean flavours in Hungary

paragraphs.text:
The facade reveals a ruin bar similar to the nearby streets of the old Jewish neighbourhood. Once you push the raw wood door into the lobby and its old walls, Mazel Tov opens up to a large and enchanting chic-industrial space with a glass roof and suspended plants that cover the footbridge leading to the first floor. Seating on turquoise iron-wrought chairs, food lovers come to share Mediterranean food, from Morocco to Israel.
In the back of the room, a gaming area welcomes kids, who need not be asked twice to have fun together. On the wooden tables, waiters serve all kinds of grilled food, Mazel Tov's speciality: shawarma, spicy merguez sausage, beef skewers, duck breast and so on… The restaurant also draws inspiration from Levantine street food to fill up the menu, with hummus, falafels and grilled eggplant that will please young and old alike.

content.title: Pest-Buda, Budapest's oldest hotel

introduction.small: Drawing on three centuries of existence and undeniable character, the Pest-Buda was entirely renovated to better welcome travellers

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pest-Buda, Budapest's oldest hotel

paragraphs.text:
From the outside, it is hard to immagine that the hotel opened in… 1696! The eldest of Budapest's hospitality business, Pest-Buda shows no traces of aging. The establishment has known how to modernise its infrastructure along the years, in the Buda Castle neighbourhood by the ramparts. At the same time, it retained some traces of its past since the Baroque-style brick roof is the original. For a time, the hotel had a lacklustre appearance, but the ground floor bistro has always a city hallmark.
After extensive renovation works, Pest-Buda offers ten rooms, suites and apartments. Please note that in order to preserve the integrity of the building, which is listed as a historical monument, no elevator has been installed, and rooms are therefore only accessible through the staircase. A bohemian spirit permeates the air, with the use of retro-modern designs and quality materials in a friendly atmosphere. In the morning, take your breakfast on the last floor under a glass roof. A magical moment with Budapest in the background.

content.title: Fröccsterasz Wintergarden, party in a former bus terminal

introduction.small: Deserted for years, this bus station was turned into a hotspot of Budapest's nightlife, whilst retaining its old look.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fröccsterasz Wintergarden, party in a former bus terminal

paragraphs.text:
Bordering on Erzsébet Park and not far from the St. Stephen's Basilica, this deserted bus station freshened up and now houses a trendy bar. Fröccsterasz Wintergarden still retains the original look of the building, with a clock-covered wall that gives time around the world.
This quirky Biergarten, established as a “winter garden”, has become a major player on the Budapest night scene. There, it is possible to have dinner and then dance all night to the sounds of concerts and DJ sets, depending on the line-up. When warmer days rear their heads, large terraces open up on each side of the station. With its outdoor bar and club, Fröccsterasz is one of the most popular night spots of the capital.

content.title: In the depths of the Budapest soul

introduction.small: How about discovering the "Romantic" in a whole new light, a whole new night? Here is an unusual walk in the underground of Budapest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the depths of the Budapest soul

paragraphs.text:
In Budapest, you can see a forgotten labyrinth 10 to 15 metres under the Buda castle, a secret cave converted into a Catholic church years ago and winding rock mazes that are hundreds of thousands of years old. Renowned for its thermal baths, developed after the Ottoman presence in the 16th century, the city has other unique attractions to offer. Indeed, this beautiful cosmopolitan city also called the pearl of the Danube, conceals miles of spectacular underground stalagmites and stalactites, crystalline formations and pisolithic concretions.

In total, you will have the opportunity to visit nearly 200 small and large excavations. Steel and stone ladders facilitate exploration of the troglodyte church of Our Lady of the Hungarians, and the Pál-völgyi or Szemlő-hegyi caves. In any season, immerse yourself in a sensational speleological adventure and dive head first into the depths of Hungarian history.

content.title: Atop Gellért Hill, all Budapest stretches out before you

introduction.small: Gain Budapest's heights and take the best possible pictures up Gellért Hill. You will boost your likes in no time!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Atop Gellért Hill, all Budapest stretches out before you

paragraphs.text:
Named after the Venetian Bishop Gerard, who was called upon by the first king of the country to convert the population to Christianity, Gellért Hill overlooks the Hungarian capital and its surroundings. Legend has it that in 1046 when the pagan revolt was at the height of violence, this man of the Church was captured and closed up in a barrel laden with nails and thrown into the Danube from the heights of the city.

Climb up this block of dolomite which, in the last millennium, rose up high above the river to today offer you its grace as a gift. Here a statue of liberty watches over the city, arms upraised. A citadel stands proudly behind her, built by the Austrians after the popular uprising of 1848, a reminder of Habsburg power and the sacrifices of the Soviet troops to liberate Hungary. The Danube, whose surface is blown by the wind, flows between Buda and Pest to form one city, that of Budapest.

content.title: Farm, a gastro pub

introduction.small: Among the ‘ruin bars', Farm is an exception with its almost minimalist decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Farm, a gastro pub

paragraphs.text:
Farm has the usual “skeleton” of a romkert (ruin garden), one of these “ruin bars” typical of the city, built around a courtyard. But the resemblance ends there. The walls of this gastro-pub are dressed in bright white, while old farm utensils (saws, hammers, spades) give an almost minimalist touch to the whole. And it is chic. Diplomats, expats and locals come to enjoy a cocktail – in moderation – prepared by Gergely,  known as Jack by the regulars. He likes nothing better than working ‘real' fruits associated with high quality spirits. In summer, Jack tours the small producers whose strawberries, raspberries or currants he freezes, which then brighten the grey of winter. A kiwi or a dried apricot come to rest on the rim of your glass. With or without alcohol, plates of cheeses and cold meats can accompany his creations from the nearby farms. How could it be otherwise when the bar is called “Farm”?

content.title: Kiosk, refined design

introduction.small: Day and night, Kiosk is the trendy restaurant-cafe favoured by Budapest's youth.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kiosk, refined design

paragraphs.text:
‘Happiness is not a destination, it's a way of life',  you can read on the waitress' t-shirt, and Kiosk makes sure to keep their end of the bargain. Facing the Danube, Kiosk is the café restaurant with the wind in its sails, where evenings with friends follow upon business lunches. The menu features seasonal soup (green pea cream soup in winter, and of course goulash) followed, for example, by cabbage and carrot risotto. There are also a number of vegetarian choices while those sensitive to gluten and lactose are also taken into consideration. On the decor side, the brick walls are falsely crumbling and lined with original theatre alcoves. In the evening, frenzied night owls pound the parquet to the rhythm of DJ turntables. In summer, a large terrace unfolds its tables outside the building, for the families' greatest enjoyment.

content.title: Franz Liszt Academy of Music, soaring music

introduction.small: The greatest musicians have left their legacy in Budapest. The music of Franz Liszt is among the most impacting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Franz Liszt Academy of Music, soaring music

paragraphs.text:
Already from the street, you might hear a few notes floating out of the rehearsal rooms. Follow your ears and open the door of this building. The music caresses the ears and warms the heart while the eyes dart about admiring this crumbling decor of frescoes, stained glass, mosaics and crystal chandeliers... The Franz Liszt Academy of Music, founded by the Hungarian composer in 1907 is an architectural Art Nouveau masterpiece whose skeleton is still regarded as an engineering marvel. Refurbished a few years ago, the walls have regained their original colour and decoration in a profusion of gold leaf - the communist ideological imprint having been removed. The tapestries and curtains are reminiscent of the opulence of the early 20th century. To best take advantage of all this, you must choose a concert from the rich musical programme, ranging from intimate quartets to large orchestras. You can also admire the magnificent fountain signed by Mika Róth, on the ground floor.

content.title: A market of small producers… in a tendy bar

introduction.small: Better known for its wild nights, the Szimpla Kert bar turns into a producers market on Sunday.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A market of small producers… in a tendy bar

paragraphs.text:
On Saturday night, revellers invade the Szimpla Kert bar. On Sunday morning, local ‘bobos' do their shopping. It's a neat turnaround for this court of miracles from which Cinderella may seem to have escaped. The legendary Szimpla Kert was one of the first romkert (literally “ruin bars”) to open in the Erzsebetvaros neighbourhood. Built around courtyards and patios, the building is filled with bric-a-brac furniture where a bath has been transformed into a sofa, grandmother lamps provide warm light, an old bike is ‘parked' on a wall covered with graffiti, and there is a vintage fussball (that still works!). With shots of vodka and pálinka (the local fruit brandy) to be enjoyed in moderation, foreign tongues ​​are loosened. On Sunday morning, Hungarian takes over. While tourists are still sleeping, the locals come to fill their baskets with provisions (blushing tomatoes, tasty cheeses, jams to die for) from small producers from this local market with live music. Pay a visit without further ado!

Szimpla Kert

content.title: Hotel Nemzeti Budapest – theatrical elegance

introduction.small: The walls of the hotel still bear the mark of the National Theatre that stood next door. Ideal to dream up the classics!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Nemzeti Budapest – theatrical elegance

paragraphs.text:
Legend has it that a tunnel used to link the hotel to the old neighbouring National Theatre. Actors and actresses would have taken it for discrete trysts.

Built in 1896 in a very eclectic style, the Hotel Nemzeti (‘National') flourished along with the neighbourhood. It was one of the first to offer central heating and in the bedrooms, electric light near the bed. The bourgeoisie and the aristocracy of the time tread the Carrara marble staircase and held salons under the canopy. Now renovated, this five-star hotel has retained its beautiful facade and its elegant glass roof, under which breakfast is served.

Its 80 rooms and suites range in tone from muted to more vivid colours, combining the practical with the pleasant. Though the National Theatre moved long ago, the hotel has maintained ties with the stage, and visits backstage may be organised on request.

introduction.small: Do the splits between Buda and Pest, juggling between the past and the present, and fall asleep facing the Danube.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lánchíd 19 – design at the foot of the castle

Below the castle, Lánchíd 19 lazes on the Buda banks, embracing Pest with its gaze from behind a facade of glass.

Opened in the 2000s, it was the first design hotel in the city—and the only one, to date, to be part of the Design Hotels network. Its contemporary architecture offers a complete break with the 19th century landscape that surrounds it. But not only. The past blends with the present in the lobby whose floor of glass, once again, reveals Roman ruins. You can admire them from the Alvar Aalto chairs, a nice nod to this temporal pirouette. As for the rooms, they are turned outwards, looking from one side towards the castle, and from the other towards the Danube. Some have balconies.

The panoramic suite opens on three sides. When the veil of night falls, the city is illuminated with thousands of lights and the view becomes magical.

content.title: Budapest Poster Gallery, poster displays

introduction.small: This gallery-shop offers a graphic window into the country's history. It also makes it possible to dress your walls in an original manner.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Budapest Poster Gallery, poster displays

paragraphs.text:
Just like Poland and the former Czechoslovakia are known for their graphic design and poster cultures, Hungary was also built on images and typography. The Budapest Poster Gallery brings together a rare collection of posters from the late 19th to the 20th centuries. "The collection opens a window onto the past," suggests Ádám Várkonyi, the founder of this special gallery. "These posters were not created with a view to lasting a long time, but to make an immediate impression." Like snapshots through time, they offer a reading of the history of the country via their drawings and colours. The golden age of Art Nouveau contrasts with the ‘commercial' propaganda posters and advertisements extolling the unbranded (‘shoe store shoes' or ‘cheap, fashionable and good quality clothes'). You will find little lightweight treasures that are easy to slip into a suitcase at reasonable prices. To plan a visit, you simply have to contact the gallery by phone or on their website.

content.title: 100% Hungarian shopping

introduction.small: Looking for a typical souvenir of Hungary? Hurry a visit to Mono Art & Design and Tisza Cipő!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 100% Hungarian shopping

paragraphs.text:
For traditional souvenirs (paprika, pálinka, sausage, embroidered shirts or colourful cushions), we recommend the aisles of the large central Nagycsarnok market. But if you are looking for more contemporary design, choose the Mono Art & Design shop. This concept store collects the gems of local creation: from fine ceramics to notebooks that bring new meaning to writing, through children's toys (which might actually get them to let go of their tablet and mobile phones)... Over a hundred designers are represented in these 300 m2, regularly animated by exhibitions. The cherry on the cake? Ykra backpacks inspired by the look of the 70s. Another address to check out is Tisza Cipő sneakers, which started beating the pavement in 1949, during the height of the communist period. After a slowdown during the regime change, they are once again on the rise having become popular with the youth population.

content.title: Macesz Bistro, traditional dishes revisited

introduction.small: Near the largest synagogue in Europe, Macesz Bistro celebrates Jewish culinary tradition, while giving it a modern twist.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Macesz Bistro, traditional dishes revisited

paragraphs.text:
Erzsébetváros, the old Jewish quarter, invites walking day and night - this is where the party is in full swing in all the romkert (“ruin bars”). Cross Gozsdu Passage, a row of six courtyards, lined with restaurants and bars where you will be spoiled for choice for an appetiser. Just steps away, Macesz Bistro will invite you to discover the flavours of an Eastern European brasserie, combining Jewish and Hungarian recipes revisited with a contemporary sauce. From lamb goulash to egg shakshuka and duck breast served with typical cabbage cream, the menu stirs the appetite. With white tablecloths and bistro chairs, the atmosphere is relaxed and friendly. On the walls, mirrors of all sizes are found alongside silver trays. Farther on, there is a child's rocking horse swinging from the ceiling and the hooks of the coat rack are composed of tableware. The decor is a reflection of the treasures of this traditional, innovative cuisine with multiple influences.

content.title: Back to the past in this statue cemetary to the glory of communism. Ideal to put yourself in the shoes spy from the Soviet era!

introduction.small: This statue cemetery gathers a sample of the monuments that previously adorned the streets and squares of the country, to the glory of communism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Back to the past in this statue cemetary to the glory of communism. Ideal to put yourself in the shoes spy from the Soviet era!

paragraphs.text:
The pair of bronze boots standing on a pedestal is unusual in this remote corner of Budapest. This is a replica of Stalin's shoes whose statue was toppled on October 23, 1956 during the uprising against the Russians. The crowd cut the bronze (and iron) man to pieces in a few short hours. Only the boots remained before disappearing in turn. Placed before this outdoor museum, they symbolise the defeat of the dictatorship.

The statues of the park include monuments that were erected to the glory of workers and personalities of the Soviet era, but it's advisable to take a guide to fully understand everything. Projections of black and white films showing the training of (real) agents and indicators of the former Hungarian secret police may be seen in the screening room. You will learn how to search a house from top to bottom without disturbing anything and how to use a camera hidden in a handbag. After this visit, you will never watch a spy film the same way again.

Brody House, their hotel with its B&B airs, attracts an audience of trendy aesthetes, drawn by this intimate residence with squeaky floors. A friendly feeling reigns in the common rooms, bathed in light, where you will feel at home with friends. The cosy rooms feature ‘re-enchanted' furniture created by artists during a residency. For a more exclusive stay, register an option (from May) for the Brody House Writer's Villa, located in the hills of Budapest. The former love nest of a baron and his ballerina in the late 19th century, this house will take you back in time - and maybe even encourage you to jump from the first floor balcony into the outdoor pool! content.title: Buda, the better to see Pest

introduction.small: A romantic walk with a touch of tourism in this quiet corner of the city. A must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Buda, the better to see Pest

paragraphs.text:
Do not brood over Buda. This side of the Danube offers a quiet charm that is almost bucolic. At the end of the Chain Bridge, the castle has dominated the hill since the 13th century.

Transformed by the Habsburgs and rebuilt after World War II, it now houses the Hungarian National Gallery—the largest collection of Hungarian art from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. It also organises temporary exhibitions. Well worth the time, as is the surrounding neighbourhood, classed as a UNESCO World Heritage site. You need to lose yourself in the cobbled streets lined with colourful houses, such as those of Fortuna Street.

Now restored, it has become very touristy, sporting a look that is a tad ‘cardboard' but full of charm. The Matthias Church will astonish you with its covered roof of polychrome tiles, as will the Fishermen's Bastion, an amazing Neo-Romanesque style ensemble where you can enjoy an aperitif while admiring the beautiful view over Pest.

content.title: Széchenyi baths, discover the “blue gold”

introduction.small: Put on your bathing suit to enjoy the city's baths.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Széchenyi baths, discover the “blue gold”

paragraphs.text:
Summer or winter, it's in a swimsuit that you will best discover Budapest. More than a ritual, baths are a social rendezvous where people gather to chat, swim or play chess. To take care of oneself too. The city has more than a hundred underground springs, some of them with recognised health virtues. Romans and Turks were not mistaken in founding the baths and raising them to an art of living. “Blue gold” flows everywhere.

Among the many thermal spots, Széchenyi remains one of the most impressive. Located in the City Park, the neo-Baroque coral yellow building has a dozen indoor pools and three outdoor pools. It's like a picture postcard with the warm water and steam, and the bathers outdoors indulging in crazy chess games that they will stop for nothing - not even snow. Rich in calcium, magnesium and carbonic acid, the Széchenyi water relieves joint pain, arthritis and stimulates the nervous system.

content.title: The photographs of the Robert Capa Contemporary Photography Centre

introduction.small: Just steps away from Andrássy Avenue, this space champions the work of the greatest photographers and upcoming talents

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The photographs of the Robert Capa Contemporary Photography Centre

paragraphs.text:
Robert Capa (1913-1954) is undoubtedly one of the most famous photographers of the 20th century. His real Hungarian name was Endre Ernő Friedmann. He left Budapest in 1931 to travel to Berlin and Paris. In 1936, during the civil war in Spain he took a photo of a militiaman struck by a bullet, which immediately made him famous. His career as a war photographer was launched. His slogan? “If your picture isn't good enough, you're not close enough.”

This phrase still resonates today in school darkrooms. In the US, he co-founded the famous Magnum photographers' cooperative in 1947. He died in Indochina after stepping on a mine. The Robert Capa Contemporary Photography Centre pays tribute to him by organising temporary exhibitions alternating big names in photography and young talents. Rare Robert Capa colour snapshots are regularly exposed there.
